Random map generation in Godot üó∫

22 April 2021

Recently, I‚Äôve been looking into how to create random maps in Godot. The topic of creating something, like a map, with just a few lines of code has always interested me. I haven‚Äôt done anything like this yet, but I‚Äôm working on a small project where I can easily implement this.

The basic idea is simple, you create a noise map by a random noise algorithm (like the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù Perlin noise or the improved and open source version, the OpenSimplex Noise) and based on this noise the map is created. Noise algorithms are a very interesting topic in their own right, which I may go into in more detail in the future, but for now let‚Äôs move on. In Godot, you can easily create noise using the OpenSimplexNoise class. You can use the get_image() method to create a noise image that looks like this, for example:

You are probably asking yourself, how do we get from this to a map? Well, as mentioned the basic idea is simple, for each pixel we now have a float value between 0 and 1. You can now assign a specific tile (e.g. grass) for each subrange from 0 to 1 (e.g. 0.25 to 0.50).

Sidenote: For my project I used a tileset from kenney.nl, which I recommend for prototyping.

That is, you take the noise image, loop through each pixel, and assign a specific tile based on the value of that pixel. That‚Äôs the basic idea, you can see a playable example (works best on the desktop) on my itch.io page, or click the link below. I also have the source code on my GitHub page, see Evolution, as this example is part of a small project I‚Äôm working on.
